context: Otherwise, no cell growth was observed. Although xylose and other pentoses are not good substrates of R. eutropha, their derivative furfural is a good substrate. Its concentration declines quickly from initial 1 to 2g/L to below 0.01g/L in 48h as shown in Fig. 3 . Since furfural is an aldehyde (furan-2-carboxaldehyde) derived mainly from xylose, R. eutropha may also be able to use other poor substrate sugars such as arabinose after they are converted to aldehydes. This needs further investigation. Catechol(1,2-dihydroxybenzene) is a poor substrate for growth of R. eutropha as shown in Fig. 1. But its biological oxidation occurs very fast as observed with a quick color change during cultivation.
